speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The palace.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Flourish of trumpets: then hautboys. Enter KING  HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and  CARDINAL, on the one side; QUEEN MARGARET, SUFFOLK, YORK, SOMERSET, and BUCKINGHAM, on the other

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: As by your high imperial majesty

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I had in charge at my depart for France,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: As procurator to your excellence,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To marry Princess Margaret for your grace,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So, in the famous ancient city, Tours,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: In presence of the Kings of France and Sicil,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The Dukes of Orleans, Calaber, Bretagne and Alencon,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Seven earls, twelve barons and twenty reverend bishops,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I have perform'd my task and was espoused:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And humbly now upon my bended knee,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: In sight of England and her lordly peers,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Deliver up my title in the queen

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To your most gracious hands, that are the substance

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Of that great shadow I did represent;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The happiest gift that ever marquess gave,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The fairest queen that ever king received.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Suffolk, arise. Welcome, Queen Margaret:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I can express no kinder sign of love

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than this kind kiss. O Lord, that lends me life,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For thou hast given me in this beauteous face

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A world of earthly blessings to my soul,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If sympathy of love unite our thoughts.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Great King of England and my gracious lord,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The mutual conference that my mind hath had,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: By day, by night, waking and in my dreams,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: In courtly company or at my beads,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With you, mine alder-liefest sovereign,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Makes me the bolder to salute my king

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With ruder terms, such as my wit affords

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And over-joy of heart doth minister.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Her sight did ravish; but her grace in speech,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Her words y-clad with wisdom's majesty,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Makes me from wondering fall to weeping joys;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Such is the fulness of my heart's content.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lords, with one cheerful voice welcome my love.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: [Kneeling]  Long live Queen Margaret, England's

speaker: ALL
text_entry: happiness!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: We thank you all.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: My lord protector, so it please your grace,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Here are the articles of contracted peace

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Between our sovereign and the French king Charles,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: For eighteen months concluded by consent.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Reads]  'Imprimis, it is agreed between the French

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: king Charles, and William de la Pole, Marquess of

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Suffolk, ambassador for Henry King of England, that

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: the said Henry shall espouse the Lady Margaret,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: daughter unto Reignier King of Naples, Sicilia and

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Jerusalem, and crown her Queen of England ere the

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: thirtieth of May next ensuing. Item, that the duchy

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: of Anjou and the county of Maine shall be released

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: and delivered to the king her father'--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lets the paper fall

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Uncle, how now!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Pardon me, gracious lord;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And dimm'd mine eyes, that I can read no further.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Uncle of Winchester, I pray, read on.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: [Reads]  'Item, It is further agreed between them,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: that the duchies of Anjou and Maine shall be

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: released and delivered over to the king her father,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: and she sent over of the King of England's own

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: proper cost and charges, without having any dowry.'

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: They please us well. Lord marquess, kneel down:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We here create thee the first duke of Suffolk,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And gird thee with the sword. Cousin of York,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We here discharge your grace from being regent

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I' the parts of France, till term of eighteen months

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be full expired. Thanks, uncle Winchester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Gloucester, York, Buckingham, Somerset,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Salisbury, and Warwick;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We thank you all for the great favour done,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In entertainment to my princely queen.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, let us in, and with all speed provide

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To see her coronation be perform'd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and SUFFOLK

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brave peers of England, pillars of the state,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To you Duke Humphrey must unload his grief,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your grief, the common grief of all the land.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What! did my brother Henry spend his youth,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His valour, coin and people, in the wars?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Did he so often lodge in open field,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In winter's cold and summer's parching heat,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To conquer France, his true inheritance?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And did my brother Bedford toil his wits,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To keep by policy what Henry got?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brave York, Salisbury, and victorious Warwick,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Received deep scars in France and Normandy?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With all the learned council of the realm,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Studied so long, sat in the council-house

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Early and late, debating to and fro

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And had his highness in his infancy

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Crowned in Paris in despite of foes?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And shall these labours and these honours die?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall Henry's conquest, Bedford's vigilance,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your deeds of war and all our counsel die?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O peers of England, shameful is this league!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Fatal this marriage, cancelling your fame,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Blotting your names from books of memory,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Razing the characters of your renown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Defacing monuments of conquer'd France,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Undoing all, as all had never been!

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Nephew, what means this passionate discourse,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: This peroration with such circumstance?

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: For France, 'tis ours; and we will keep it still.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ay, uncle, we will keep it, if we can;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But now it is impossible we should:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Suffolk, the new-made duke that rules the roast,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath given the duchy of Anjou and Maine

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unto the poor King Reignier, whose large style

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Now, by the death of Him that died for all,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: These counties were the keys of Normandy.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But wherefore weeps Warwick, my valiant son?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For grief that they are past recovery:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For, were there hope to conquer them again,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My sword should shed hot blood, mine eyes no tears.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Anjou and Maine! myself did win them both;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And are the cities, that I got with wounds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Delivered up again with peaceful words?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Mort Dieu!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For Suffolk's duke, may he be suffocate,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That dims the honour of this warlike isle!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: France should have torn and rent my very heart,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Before I would have yielded to this league.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I never read but England's kings have had

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And our King Henry gives away his own,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To match with her that brings no vantages.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A proper jest, and never heard before,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That Suffolk should demand a whole fifteenth

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For costs and charges in transporting her!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She should have stayed in France and starved

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: in France, Before--

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: My Lord of Gloucester, now ye grow too hot:

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: It was the pleasure of my lord the King.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My Lord of Winchester, I know your mind;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis not my speeches that you do mislike,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But 'tis my presence that doth trouble ye.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Rancour will out: proud prelate, in thy face

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I see thy fury: if I longer stay,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We shall begin our ancient bickerings.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lordings, farewell; and say, when I am gone,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I prophesied France will be lost ere long.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: So, there goes our protector in a rage.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: 'Tis known to you he is mine enemy,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Nay, more, an enemy unto you all,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: And no great friend, I fear me, to the king.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Consider, lords, he is the next of blood,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: And heir apparent to the English crown:

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Had Henry got an empire by his marriage,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: And all the wealthy kingdoms of the west,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: There's reason he should be displeased at it.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Look to it, lords! let not his smoothing words

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: What though the common people favour him,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Calling him 'Humphrey, the good Duke of

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Gloucester,'

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Clapping their hands, and crying with loud voice,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: 'Jesu maintain your royal excellence!'

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: With 'God preserve the good Duke Humphrey!'

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: I fear me, lords, for all this flattering gloss,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: He will be found a dangerous protector.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Why should he, then, protect our sovereign,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He being of age to govern of himself?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Cousin of Somerset, join you with me,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And all together, with the Duke of Suffolk,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We'll quickly hoise Duke Humphrey from his seat.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: This weighty business will not brook delay:

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: I'll to the Duke of Suffolk presently.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Cousin of Buckingham, though Humphrey's pride

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And greatness of his place be grief to us,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Yet let us watch the haughty cardinal:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: His insolence is more intolerable

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Than all the princes in the land beside:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If Gloucester be displaced, he'll be protector.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or thou or I, Somerset, will be protector,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Despite Duke Humphrey or the cardinal.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and SOMERSET

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Pride went before, ambition follows him.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: While these do labour for their own preferment,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Behoves it us to labour for the realm.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Did bear him like a noble gentleman.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Oft have I seen the haughty cardinal,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: More like a soldier than a man o' the church,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: As stout and proud as he were lord of all,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Swear like a ruffian and demean himself

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Unlike the ruler of a commonweal.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Warwick, my son, the comfort of my age,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Thy deeds, thy plainness and thy housekeeping,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Hath won the greatest favour of the commons,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Excepting none but good Duke Humphrey:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And, brother York, thy acts in Ireland,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: In bringing them to civil discipline,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Thy late exploits done in the heart of France,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: When thou wert regent for our sovereign,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Have made thee fear'd and honour'd of the people:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Join we together, for the public good,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: In what we can, to bridle and suppress

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The pride of Suffolk and the cardinal,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: With Somerset's and Buckingham's ambition;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And, as we may, cherish Duke Humphrey's deeds,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: While they do tend the profit of the land.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So God help Warwick, as he loves the land,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And common profit of his country!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: [Aside]  And so says York, for he hath greatest cause.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Then let's make haste away, and look unto the main.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unto the main! O father, Maine is lost;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That Maine which by main force Warwick did win,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And would have kept so long as breath did last!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Main chance, father, you meant; but I meant Maine,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Which I will win from France, or else be slain,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt WARWICK and SALISBURY

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Anjou and Maine are given to the French;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Paris is lost; the state of Normandy

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Stands on a tickle point, now they are gone:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Suffolk concluded on the articles,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The peers agreed, and Henry was well pleased

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To change two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I cannot blame them all: what is't to them?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Tis thine they give away, and not their own.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And purchase friends and give to courtezans,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Still revelling like lords till all be gone;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While as the silly owner of the goods

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Weeps over them and wrings his hapless hands

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And shakes his head and trembling stands aloof,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While all is shared and all is borne away,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ready to starve and dare not touch his own:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While his own lands are bargain'd for and sold.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Methinks the realms of England, France and Ireland

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As did the fatal brand Althaea burn'd

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Unto the prince's heart of Calydon.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Anjou and Maine both given unto the French!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Cold news for me, for I had hope of France,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Even as I have of fertile England's soil.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A day will come when York shall claim his own;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And therefore I will take the Nevils' parts

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, when I spy advantage, claim the crown,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For that's the golden mark I seek to hit:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nor wear the diadem upon his head,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose church-like humours fits not for a crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then, York, be still awhile, till time do serve:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Watch thou and wake when others be asleep,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To pry into the secrets of the state;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till Henry, surfeiting in joys of love,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With his new bride and England's dear-bought queen,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And Humphrey with the peers be fall'n at jars:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With whose sweet smell the air shall be perfumed;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And in my standard bear the arms of York

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To grapple with the house of Lancaster;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, force perforce, I'll make him yield the crown,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose bookish rule hath pull'd fair England down.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: YORK
text_entry: SCENE II. GLOUCESTER'S house.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER and his DUCHESS

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Why droops my lord, like over-ripen'd corn,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Hanging the head at Ceres' plenteous load?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: As frowning at the favours of the world?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Gazing on that which seems to dim thy sight?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What seest thou there? King Henry's diadem,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Enchased with all the honours of the world?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: If so, gaze on, and grovel on thy face,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Until thy head be circled with the same.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious gold.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What, is't too short? I'll lengthen it with mine:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And, having both together heaved it up,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: We'll both together lift our heads to heaven,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And never more abase our sight so low

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O Nell, sweet Nell, if thou dost love thy lord,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And may that thought, when I imagine ill

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Against my king and nephew, virtuous Henry,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be my last breathing in this mortal world!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My troublous dream this night doth make me sad.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What dream'd my lord? tell me, and I'll requite it

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With sweet rehearsal of my morning's dream.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Methought this staff, mine office-badge in court,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Was broke in twain; by whom I have forgot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, as I think, it was by the cardinal;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And on the pieces of the broken wand

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Were placed the heads of Edmund Duke of Somerset,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And William de la Pole, first duke of Suffolk.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This was my dream: what it doth bode, God knows.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Tut, this was nothing but an argument

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Shall lose his head for his presumption.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But list to me, my Humphrey, my sweet duke:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Methought I sat in seat of majesty

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In the cathedral church of Westminster,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And in that chair where kings and queens are crown'd;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Where Henry and dame Margaret kneel'd to me

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And on my head did set the diadem.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, Eleanor, then must I chide outright:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Presumptuous dame, ill-nurtured Eleanor,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Art thou not second woman in the realm,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And the protector's wife, beloved of him?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Above the reach or compass of thy thought?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And wilt thou still be hammering treachery,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To tumble down thy husband and thyself

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From top of honour to disgrace's feet?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Away from me, and let me hear no more!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What, what, my lord! are you so choleric

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With Eleanor, for telling but her dream?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Next time I'll keep my dreams unto myself,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And not be cheque'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, be not angry; I am pleased again.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord protector, 'tis his highness' pleasure

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: You do prepare to ride unto Saint Alban's,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Where as the king and queen do mean to hawk.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I go. Come, Nell, thou wilt ride with us?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yes, my good lord, I'll follow presently.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exeunt GLOUCESTER and Messenger

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Follow I must; I cannot go before,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: While Gloucester bears this base and humble mind.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Were I a man, a duke, and next of blood,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I would remove these tedious stumbling-blocks

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And smooth my way upon their headless necks;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And, being a woman, I will not be slack

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To play my part in Fortune's pageant.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Where are you there? Sir John! nay, fear not, man,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: We are alone; here's none but thee and I.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Enter HUME

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Jesus preserve your royal majesty!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What say'st thou? majesty! I am but grace.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: But, by the grace of God, and Hume's advice,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Your grace's title shall be multiplied.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What say'st thou, man? hast thou as yet conferr'd

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With Margery Jourdain, the cunning witch,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With Roger Bolingbroke, the conjurer?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And will they undertake to do me good?

speaker: HUME
text_entry: This they have promised, to show your highness

speaker: HUME
text_entry: A spirit raised from depth of under-ground,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: That shall make answer to such questions

speaker: HUME
text_entry: As by your grace shall be propounded him.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: It is enough; I'll think upon the questions:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: When from St. Alban's we do make return,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: We'll see these things effected to the full.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Here, Hume, take this reward; make merry, man,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With thy confederates in this weighty cause.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Hume must make merry with the duchess' gold;

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Marry, and shall. But how now, Sir John Hume!

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Seal up your lips, and give no words but mum:

speaker: HUME
text_entry: The business asketh silent secrecy.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Dame Eleanor gives gold to bring the witch:

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Gold cannot come amiss, were she a devil.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Yet have I gold flies from another coast;

speaker: HUME
text_entry: I dare not say, from the rich cardinal

speaker: HUME
text_entry: And from the great and new-made Duke of Suffolk,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Yet I do find it so; for to be plain,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: They, knowing Dame Eleanor's aspiring humour,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Have hired me to undermine the duchess

speaker: HUME
text_entry: And buz these conjurations in her brain.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: They say 'A crafty knave does need no broker;'

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Yet am I Suffolk and the cardinal's broker.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Hume, if you take not heed, you shall go near

speaker: HUME
text_entry: To call them both a pair of crafty knaves.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Well, so it stands; and thus, I fear, at last

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Hume's knavery will be the duchess' wreck,

speaker: HUME
text_entry: And her attainture will be Humphrey's fall:

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Sort how it will, I shall have gold for all.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HUME
text_entry: SCENE III. The palace.

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Enter three or four Petitioners, PETER, the Armourer's man, being one

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: My masters, let's stand close: my lord protector

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: will come this way by and by, and then we may deliver

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: our supplications in the quill.

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: Marry, the Lord protect him, for he's a good man!

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: Jesu bless him!

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: Enter SUFFOLK and QUEEN MARGARET

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Here a' comes, methinks, and the queen with him.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I'll be the first, sure.

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: Come back, fool; this is the Duke of Suffolk, and

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: not my lord protector.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: How now, fellow! would'st anything with me?

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: I pray, my lord, pardon me; I took ye for my lord

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: protector.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: [Reading]  'To my Lord Protector!' Are your

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: supplications to his lordship? Let me see them:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: what is thine?

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: Mine is, an't please your grace, against John

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: Goodman, my lord cardinal's man, for keeping my

speaker: First Petitioner
text_entry: house, and lands, and wife and all, from me.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thy wife, too! that's some wrong, indeed. What's

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: yours? What's here!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Reads

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: 'Against the Duke of Suffolk, for enclosing the

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: commons of Melford.' How now, sir knave!

speaker: Second Petitioner
text_entry: Alas, sir, I am but a poor petitioner of our whole township.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: [Giving his petition]  Against my master, Thomas

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Horner, for saying that the Duke of York was rightful

speaker: PETER
text_entry: heir to the crown.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What sayst thou? did the Duke of York say he was

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: rightful heir to the crown?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: That my master was? no, forsooth: my master said

speaker: PETER
text_entry: that he was, and that the king was an usurper.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Who is there?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Enter Servant

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Take this fellow in, and send for

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: his master with a pursuivant presently: we'll hear

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: more of your matter before the King.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exit Servant with PETER

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And as for you, that love to be protected

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Under the wings of our protector's grace,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Begin your suits anew, and sue to him.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Tears the supplication

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Away, base cullions! Suffolk, let them go.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Come, let's be gone.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My Lord of Suffolk, say, is this the guise,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Is this the fashion in the court of England?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Is this the government of Britain's isle,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And this the royalty of Albion's king?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What shall King Henry be a pupil still

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Under the surly Gloucester's governance?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Am I a queen in title and in style,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And must be made a subject to a duke?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I tell thee, Pole, when in the city Tours

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou ran'st a tilt in honour of my love

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And stolest away the ladies' hearts of France,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I thought King Henry had resembled thee

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: In courage, courtship and proportion:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But all his mind is bent to holiness,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To number Ave-Maries on his beads;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His champions are the prophets and apostles,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His weapons holy saws of sacred writ,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His study is his tilt-yard, and his loves

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Are brazen images of canonized saints.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I would the college of the cardinals

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Would choose him pope, and carry him to Rome,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And set the triple crown upon his head:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That were a state fit for his holiness.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Madam, be patient: as I was cause

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Your highness came to England, so will I

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: In England work your grace's full content.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Beside the haughty protector, have we Beaufort,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The imperious churchman, Somerset, Buckingham,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And grumbling York: and not the least of these

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But can do more in England than the king.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And he of these that can do most of all

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Cannot do more in England than the Nevils:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Salisbury and Warwick are no simple peers.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Not all these lords do vex me half so much

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As that proud dame, the lord protector's wife.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: She sweeps it through the court with troops of ladies,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: More like an empress than Duke Humphrey's wife:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Strangers in court do take her for the queen:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: She bears a duke's revenues on her back,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And in her heart she scorns our poverty:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Shall I not live to be avenged on her?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Contemptuous base-born callet as she is,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: She vaunted 'mongst her minions t'other day,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The very train of her worst wearing gown

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Was better worth than all my father's lands,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Till Suffolk gave two dukedoms for his daughter.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Madam, myself have limed a bush for her,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And placed a quire of such enticing birds,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That she will light to listen to the lays,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And never mount to trouble you again.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So, let her rest: and, madam, list to me;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: For I am bold to counsel you in this.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Although we fancy not the cardinal,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Yet must we join with him and with the lords,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Till we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: As for the Duke of York, this late complaint

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Will make but little for his benefit.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: So, one by one, we'll weed them all at last,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And you yourself shall steer the happy helm.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER,  CARDINAL, BUCKINGHAM, YORK, SOMERSET, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and the DUCHESS

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For my part, noble lords, I care not which;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or Somerset or York, all's one to me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If York have ill demean'd himself in France,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then let him be denay'd the regentship.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If Somerset be unworthy of the place,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Let York be regent; I will yield to him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Whether your grace be worthy, yea or no,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dispute not that: York is the worthier.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Ambitious Warwick, let thy betters speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The cardinal's not my better in the field.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: All in this presence are thy betters, Warwick.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Warwick may live to be the best of all.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Peace, son! and show some reason, Buckingham,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Why Somerset should be preferred in this.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Because the king, forsooth, will have it so.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, the king is old enough himself

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To give his censure: these are no women's matters.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If he be old enough, what needs your grace

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To be protector of his excellence?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, I am protector of the realm;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, at his pleasure, will resign my place.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Resign it then and leave thine insolence.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Since thou wert king--as who is king but thou?--

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The commonwealth hath daily run to wreck;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The Dauphin hath prevail'd beyond the seas;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And all the peers and nobles of the realm

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Have been as bondmen to thy sovereignty.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: The commons hast thou rack'd; the clergy's bags

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Are lank and lean with thy extortions.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's attire

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Have cost a mass of public treasury.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Thy cruelty in execution

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon offenders, hath exceeded law,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And left thee to the mercy of the law.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: They sale of offices and towns in France,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If they were known, as the suspect is great,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Would make thee quickly hop without thy head.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exit GLOUCESTER. QUEEN MARGARET drops her fan

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Give me my fan: what, minion! can ye not?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: She gives the DUCHESS a box on the ear

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I cry you mercy, madam; was it you?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Was't I! yea, I it was, proud Frenchwoman:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Could I come near your beauty with my nails,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I'd set my ten commandments in your face.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sweet aunt, be quiet; 'twas against her will.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Against her will! good king, look to't in time;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: She'll hamper thee, and dandle thee like a baby:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Though in this place most master wear no breeches,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: She shall not strike Dame Eleanor unrevenged.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord cardinal, I will follow Eleanor,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And listen after Humphrey, how he proceeds:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: She's tickled now; her fume needs no spurs,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: She'll gallop far enough to her destruction.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Re-enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now, lords, my choler being over-blown

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With walking once about the quadrangle,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I come to talk of commonwealth affairs.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As for your spiteful false objections,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Prove them, and I lie open to the law:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But God in mercy so deal with my soul,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As I in duty love my king and country!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, to the matter that we have in hand:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I say, my sovereign, York is meetest man

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be your regent in the realm of France.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Before we make election, give me leave

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: To show some reason, of no little force,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That York is most unmeet of any man.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I'll tell thee, Suffolk, why I am unmeet:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: First, for I cannot flatter thee in pride;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Next, if I be appointed for the place,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My Lord of Somerset will keep me here,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Without discharge, money, or furniture,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till France be won into the Dauphin's hands:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Last time, I danced attendance on his will

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till Paris was besieged, famish'd, and lost.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That can I witness; and a fouler fact

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Did never traitor in the land commit.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Peace, headstrong Warwick!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Image of pride, why should I hold my peace?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter HORNER, the Armourer, and his man PETER, guarded

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Because here is a man accused of treason:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Pray God the Duke of York excuse himself!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Doth any one accuse York for a traitor?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What mean'st thou, Suffolk; tell me, what are these?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Please it your majesty, this is the man

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That doth accuse his master of high treason:

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: His words were these: that Richard, Duke of York,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Was rightful heir unto the English crown

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And that your majesty was a usurper.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Say, man, were these thy words?

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: An't shall please your majesty, I never said nor

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: thought any such matter: God is my witness, I am

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: falsely accused by the villain.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: By these ten bones, my lords, he did speak them to

speaker: PETER
text_entry: me in the garret one night, as we were scouring my

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Lord of York's armour.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Base dunghill villain and mechanical,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I'll have thy head for this thy traitor's speech.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I do beseech your royal majesty,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let him have all the rigor of the law.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Alas, my lord, hang me, if ever I spake the words.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: My accuser is my 'prentice; and when I did correct

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: him for his fault the other day, he did vow upon his

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: knees he would be even with me: I have good

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: witness of this: therefore I beseech your majesty,

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: do not cast away an honest man for a villain's

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: accusation.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Uncle, what shall we say to this in law?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This doom, my lord, if I may judge:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let Somerset be regent over the French,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Because in York this breeds suspicion:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And let these have a day appointed them

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For single combat in convenient place,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For he hath witness of his servant's malice:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This is the law, and this Duke Humphrey's doom.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: I humbly thank your royal majesty.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: And I accept the combat willingly.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Alas, my lord, I cannot fight; for God's sake, pity

speaker: PETER
text_entry: my case. The spite of man prevaileth against me. O

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Lord, have mercy upon me! I shall never be able to

speaker: PETER
text_entry: fight a blow. O Lord, my heart!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sirrah, or you must fight, or else be hang'd.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Away with them to prison; and the day of combat

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: shall be the last of the next month. Come,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Somerset, we'll see thee sent away.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE IV. GLOUCESTER's garden.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter MARGARET JOURDAIN, HUME, SOUTHWELL, and BOLINGBROKE

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Come, my masters; the duchess, I tell you, expects

speaker: HUME
text_entry: performance of your promises.

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Master Hume, we are therefore provided: will her

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: ladyship behold and hear our exorcisms?

speaker: HUME
text_entry: Ay, what else? fear you not her courage.

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I have heard her reported to be a woman of an

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: invincible spirit: but it shall be convenient,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Master Hume, that you be by her aloft, while we be

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: busy below; and so, I pray you, go, in God's name,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: and leave us.

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exit HUME

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Mother Jourdain, be you

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: prostrate and grovel on the earth; John Southwell,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: read you; and let us to our work.

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter the DUCHESS aloft, HUME following

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Well said, my masters; and welcome all. To this

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: gear the sooner the better.

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Patience, good lady; wizards know their times:

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Deep night, dark night, the silent of the night,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The time of night when Troy was set on fire;

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The time when screech-owls cry and ban-dogs howl,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And spirits walk and ghosts break up their graves,

speaker: BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That time best fits the work we have in hand.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till Henry Bolingbroke, Duke of Lancaster,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The eldest son and heir of John of Gaunt,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Crown'd by the name of Henry the Fourth,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Seized on the realm, deposed the rightful king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sent his poor queen to France, from whence she came,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And him to Pomfret; where, as all you know,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Harmless Richard was murder'd traitorously.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Father, the duke hath told the truth:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Which now they hold by force and not by right;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For Richard, the first son's heir, being dead,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The issue of the next son should have reign'd.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But William of Hatfield died without an heir.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The third son, Duke of Clarence, from whose line

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I claimed the crown, had issue, Philippe, a daughter,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Who married Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Edmund had issue, Roger Earl of March;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Roger had issue, Edmund, Anne and Eleanor.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: This Edmund, in the reign of Bolingbroke,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: As I have read, laid claim unto the crown;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And, but for Owen Glendower, had been king,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Who kept him in captivity till he died.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But to the rest.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: His eldest sister, Anne,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My mother, being heir unto the crown

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Married Richard Earl of Cambridge; who was son

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To Edmund Langley, Edward the Third's fifth son.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By her I claim the kingdom: she was heir

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To Roger Earl of March, who was the son

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of Edmund Mortimer, who married Philippe,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sole daughter unto Lionel Duke of Clarence:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So, if the issue of the elder son

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Succeed before the younger, I am king.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What plain proceeding is more plain than this?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The fourth son; York claims it from the third.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Till Lionel's issue fails, his should not reign:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: It fails not yet, but flourishes in thee

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And in thy sons, fair slips of such a stock.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then, father Salisbury, kneel we together;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And in this private plot be we the first

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That shall salute our rightful sovereign

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With honour of his birthright to the crown.

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: Long live our sovereign Richard, England's king!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: We thank you, lords. But I am not your king

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till I be crown'd and that my sword be stain'd

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With heart-blood of the house of Lancaster;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And that's not suddenly to be perform'd,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But with advice and silent secrecy.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Do you as I do in these dangerous days:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Wink at the Duke of Suffolk's insolence,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: At Beaufort's pride, at Somerset's ambition,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: At Buckingham and all the crew of them,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till they have snared the shepherd of the flock,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That virtuous prince, the good Duke Humphrey:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Tis that they seek, and they in seeking that

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall find their deaths, if York can prophesy.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: My lord, break we off; we know your mind at full.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: My heart assures me that the Earl of Warwick

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall one day make the Duke of York a king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, Nevil, this I do assure myself:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The greatest man in England but the king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: YORK
text_entry: SCENE III. A hall of justice.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN  MARGARET, GLOUCESTER, YORK, SUFFOLK, and SALISBURY;  the DUCHESS, MARGARET JOURDAIN, SOUTHWELL, HUME, and BOLINGBROKE, under guard

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stand forth, Dame Eleanor Cobham, Gloucester's wife:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In sight of God and us, your guilt is great:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Receive the sentence of the law for sins

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Such as by God's book are adjudged to death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: You four, from hence to prison back again;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From thence unto the place of execution:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The witch in Smithfield shall be burn'd to ashes,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And you three shall be strangled on the gallows.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: You, madam, for you are more nobly born,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Despoiled of your honour in your life,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall, after three days' open penance done,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Live in your country here in banishment,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: With Sir John Stanley, in the Isle of Man.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Welcome is banishment; welcome were my death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Eleanor, the law, thou see'st, hath judged thee:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I cannot justify whom the law condemns.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt DUCHESS and other prisoners, guarded

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Mine eyes are full of tears, my heart of grief.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ah, Humphrey, this dishonour in thine age

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I beseech your majesty, give me leave to go;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sorrow would solace and mine age would ease.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stay, Humphrey Duke of Gloucester: ere thou go,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Give up thy staff: Henry will to himself

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Protector be; and God shall be my hope,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My stay, my guide and lantern to my feet:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And go in peace, Humphrey, no less beloved

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than when thou wert protector to thy King.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I see no reason why a king of years

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Should be to be protected like a child.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: God and King Henry govern England's realm.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Give up your staff, sir, and the king his realm.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My staff? here, noble Henry, is my staff:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As willingly do I the same resign

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As e'er thy father Henry made it mine;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And even as willingly at thy feet I leave it

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As others would ambitiously receive it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Farewell, good king: when I am dead and gone,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: May honourable peace attend thy throne!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, now is Henry king, and Margaret queen;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Humphrey Duke of Gloucester scarce himself,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That bears so shrewd a maim; two pulls at once;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His lady banish'd, and a limb lopp'd off.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: This staff of honour raught, there let it stand

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Where it best fits to be, in Henry's hand.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thus droops this lofty pine and hangs his sprays;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lords, let him go. Please it your majesty,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This is the day appointed for the combat;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And ready are the appellant and defendant,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The armourer and his man, to enter the lists,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So please your highness to behold the fight.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, good my lord; for purposely therefore

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Left I the court, to see this quarrel tried.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O God's name, see the lists and all things fit:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here let them end it; and God defend the right!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I never saw a fellow worse bested,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Or more afraid to fight, than is the appellant,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The servant of this armourer, my lords.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter at one door, HORNER, the Armourer, and his  Neighbours, drinking to him so much that he is drunk;  and he enters with a drum before him and his staff  with a sand-bag fastened to it; and at the other  door PETER, his man, with a drum and sand-bag, and 'Prentices drinking to him

speaker: First Neighbour
text_entry: Here, neighbour Horner, I drink to you in a cup of

speaker: First Neighbour
text_entry: sack: and fear not, neighbour, you shall do well enough.

speaker: Second Neighbour
text_entry: And here, neighbour, here's a cup of charneco.

speaker: Third Neighbour
text_entry: And here's a pot of good double beer, neighbour:

speaker: Third Neighbour
text_entry: drink, and fear not your man.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Let it come, i' faith, and I'll pledge you all; and

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: a fig for Peter!

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: First 'Prentice Here, Peter, I drink to thee: and be not afraid.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Second 'Prentice Be merry, Peter, and fear not thy master: fight

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: for credit of the 'prentices.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I thank you all: drink, and pray for me, I pray

speaker: PETER
text_entry: you; for I think I have taken my last draught in

speaker: PETER
text_entry: this world. Here, Robin, an if I die, I give thee

speaker: PETER
text_entry: my apron: and, Will, thou shalt have my hammer:

speaker: PETER
text_entry: and here, Tom, take all the money that I have. O

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Lord bless me! I pray God! for I am never able to

speaker: PETER
text_entry: deal with my master, he hath learnt me so much fence already.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Come, leave your drinking, and fall to blows.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Sirrah, what's thy name?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Peter, forsooth.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Peter! what more?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Thump.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Thump! then see thou thump thy master well.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Masters, I am come hither, as it were, upon my man's

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: honest man: and touching the Duke of York, I will

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: take my death, I never meant him any ill, nor the

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: king, nor the queen: and therefore, Peter, have at

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: thee with a downright blow!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Dispatch: this knave's tongue begins to double.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sound, trumpets, alarum to the combatants!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alarum. They fight, and PETER strikes him down

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Hold, Peter, hold! I confess, I confess treason.

speaker: HORNER
text_entry: Dies

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Take away his weapon. Fellow, thank God, and the

speaker: YORK
text_entry: good wine in thy master's way.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: O God, have I overcome mine enemy in this presence?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: O Peter, thou hast prevailed in right!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go, take hence that traitor from our sight;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For his death we do perceive his guilt:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And God in justice hath revealed to us

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The truth and innocence of this poor fellow,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Which he had thought to have murder'd wrongfully.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, fellow, follow us for thy reward.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sound a flourish. Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE IV. A street.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER and his Servingmen, in mourning cloaks

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And after summer evermore succeeds

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Barren winter, with his wrathful nipping cold:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So cares and joys abound, as seasons fleet.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sirs, what's o'clock?

speaker: Servants
text_entry: Ten, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ten is the hour that was appointed me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To watch the coming of my punish'd duchess:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Uneath may she endure the flinty streets,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To tread them with her tender-feeling feet.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sweet Nell, ill can thy noble mind abrook

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The abject people gazing on thy face,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With envious looks, laughing at thy shame,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That erst did follow thy proud chariot-wheels

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, soft! I think she comes; and I'll prepare

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My tear-stain'd eyes to see her miseries.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter the DUCHESS in a white sheet, and a taper  burning in her hand; with STANLEY, the Sheriff, and Officers

speaker: Servant
text_entry: So please your grace, we'll take her from the sheriff.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, stir not, for your lives; let her pass by.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Come you, my lord, to see my open shame?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Now thou dost penance too. Look how they gaze!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: See how the giddy multitude do point,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And nod their heads, and throw their eyes on thee!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ah, Gloucester, hide thee from their hateful looks,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And, in thy closet pent up, rue my shame,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And ban thine enemies, both mine and thine!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be patient, gentle Nell; forget this grief.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ah, Gloucester, teach me to forget myself!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: For whilst I think I am thy married wife

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And thou a prince, protector of this land,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Methinks I should not thus be led along,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Mail'd up in shame, with papers on my back,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And followed with a rabble that rejoice

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To see my tears and hear my deep-fet groans.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: The ruthless flint doth cut my tender feet,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And when I start, the envious people laugh

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And bid me be advised how I tread.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ah, Humphrey, can I bear this shameful yoke?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Trow'st thou that e'er I'll look upon the world,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Or count them happy that enjoy the sun?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: No; dark shall be my light and night my day;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To think upon my pomp shall be my hell.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Sometime I'll say, I am Duke Humphrey's wife,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And he a prince and ruler of the land:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yet so he ruled and such a prince he was

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: As he stood by whilst I, his forlorn duchess,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Was made a wonder and a pointing-stock

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To every idle rascal follower.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But be thou mild and blush not at my shame,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Nor stir at nothing till the axe of death

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Hang over thee, as, sure, it shortly will;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: For Suffolk, he that can do all in all

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With her that hateth thee and hates us all,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And York and impious Beaufort, that false priest,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Have all limed bushes to betray thy wings,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And, fly thou how thou canst, they'll tangle thee:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But fear not thou, until thy foot be snared,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Nor never seek prevention of thy foes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ah, Nell, forbear! thou aimest all awry;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I must offend before I be attainted;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And had I twenty times so many foes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And each of them had twenty times their power,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: All these could not procure me any scathe,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So long as I am loyal, true and crimeless.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, yet thy scandal were not wiped away

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But I in danger for the breach of law.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nell:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I pray thee, sort thy heart to patience;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter a Herald

speaker: Herald
text_entry: I summon your grace to his majesty's parliament,

speaker: Herald
text_entry: Holden at Bury the first of this next month.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And my consent ne'er ask'd herein before!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This is close dealing. Well, I will be there.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit Herald

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My Nell, I take my leave: and, master sheriff,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let not her penance exceed the king's commission.

speaker: Sheriff
text_entry: An't please your grace, here my commission stays,

speaker: Sheriff
text_entry: And Sir John Stanley is appointed now

speaker: Sheriff
text_entry: To take her with him to the Isle of Man.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Must you, Sir John, protect my lady here?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: So am I given in charge, may't please your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Entreat her not the worse in that I pray

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You use her well: the world may laugh again;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And I may live to do you kindness if

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You do it her: and so, Sir John, farewell!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What, gone, my lord, and bid me not farewell!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Witness my tears, I cannot stay to speak.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt GLOUCESTER and Servingmen

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Art thou gone too? all comfort go with thee!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: For none abides with me: my joy is death;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Death, at whose name I oft have been afear'd,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Because I wish'd this world's eternity.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Stanley, I prithee, go, and take me hence;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I care not whither, for I beg no favour,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Only convey me where thou art commanded.

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Why, madam, that is to the Isle of Man;

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: There to be used according to your state.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That's bad enough, for I am but reproach:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And shall I then be used reproachfully?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Like to a duchess, and Duke Humphrey's lady;

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: According to that state you shall be used.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Sheriff, farewell, and better than I fare,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Although thou hast been conduct of my shame.

speaker: Sheriff
text_entry: It is my office; and, madam, pardon me.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ay, ay, farewell; thy office is discharged.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Come, Stanley, shall we go?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Madam, your penance done, throw off this sheet,

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: And go we to attire you for our journey.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: My shame will not be shifted with my sheet:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: No, it will hang upon my richest robes

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And show itself, attire me how I can.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Go, lead the way; I long to see my prison.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: SCENE I. The Abbey at Bury St. Edmund's.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN  MARGARET, CARDINAL, SUFFOLK, YORK, BUCKINGHAM, SALISBURY and WARWICK to the Parliament

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I muse my Lord of Gloucester is not come:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: 'Tis not his wont to be the hindmost man,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whate'er occasion keeps him from us now.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Can you not see? or will ye not observe

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The strangeness of his alter'd countenance?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With what a majesty he bears himself,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How insolent of late he is become,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How proud, how peremptory, and unlike himself?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: We know the time since he was mild and affable,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And if we did but glance a far-off look,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Immediately he was upon his knee,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That all the court admired him for submission:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But meet him now, and, be it in the morn,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: When every one will give the time of day,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: He knits his brow and shows an angry eye,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And passeth by with stiff unbowed knee,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Disdaining duty that to us belongs.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Small curs are not regarded when they grin;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But great men tremble when the lion roars;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Humphrey is no little man in England.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: First note that he is near you in descent,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And should you fall, he as the next will mount.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Me seemeth then it is no policy,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Respecting what a rancorous mind he bears

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

text_entry: Thrice-noble Suffolk, 'tis resolutely spoke.

text_entry: Let pale-faced fear keep with the mean-born man,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And find no harbour in a royal heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Faster than spring-time showers comes thought

speaker: YORK
text_entry: on thought,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And not a thought but thinks on dignity.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My brain more busy than the labouring spider

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Weaves tedious snares to trap mine enemies.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Well, nobles, well, 'tis politicly done,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To send me packing with an host of men:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I fear me you but warm the starved snake,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Who, cherish'd in your breasts, will sting

speaker: YORK
text_entry: your hearts.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Twas men I lack'd and you will give them me:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I take it kindly; and yet be well assured

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You put sharp weapons in a madman's hands.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whiles I in Ireland nourish a mighty band,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I will stir up in England some black storm

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall blow ten thousand souls to heaven or hell;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And this fell tempest shall not cease to rage

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Until the golden circuit on my head,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Like to the glorious sun's transparent beams,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Do calm the fury of this mad-bred flaw.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, for a minister of my intent,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I have seduced a headstrong Kentishman,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: John Cade of Ashford,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To make commotion, as full well he can,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Under the title of John Mortimer.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In Ireland have I seen this stubborn Cade

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Oppose himself against a troop of kerns,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And fought so long, till that his thighs with darts

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Were almost like a sharp-quill'd porpentine;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, in the end being rescued, I have seen

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Him caper upright like a wild Morisco,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shaking the bloody darts as he his bells.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Full often, like a shag-hair'd crafty kern,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hath he conversed with the enemy,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And undiscover'd come to me again

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And given me notice of their villanies.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This devil here shall be my substitute;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For that John Mortimer, which now is dead,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In face, in gait, in speech, he doth resemble:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By this I shall perceive the commons' mind,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: How they affect the house and claim of York.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Say he be taken, rack'd and tortured,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I know no pain they can inflict upon him

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will make him say I moved him to those arms.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Say that he thrive, as 'tis great like he will,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why, then from Ireland come I with my strength

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And reap the harvest which that rascal sow'd;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For Humphrey being dead, as he shall be,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And Henry put apart, the next for me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: YORK
text_entry: SCENE II. Bury St. Edmund's. A room of state.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter certain Murderers, hastily

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Run to my Lord of Suffolk; let him know

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: We have dispatch'd the duke, as he commanded.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: O that it were to do! What have we done?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Didst ever hear a man so penitent?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Enter SUFFOLK

speaker: First Murder
text_entry: Here comes my lord.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Now, sirs, have you dispatch'd this thing?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Ay, my good lord, he's dead.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Why, that's well said. Go, get you to my house;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I will reward you for this venturous deed.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The king and all the peers are here at hand.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Have you laid fair the bed? Is all things well,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: According as I gave directions?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: 'Tis, my good lord.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Away! be gone.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exeunt Murderers

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, CARDINAL, SOMERSET, with Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go, call our uncle to our presence straight;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Say we intend to try his grace to-day.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If he be guilty, as 'tis published.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I'll call him presently, my noble lord.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lords, take your places; and, I pray you all,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Proceed no straiter 'gainst our uncle Gloucester

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than from true evidence of good esteem

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He be approved in practise culpable.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: God forbid any malice should prevail,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That faultless may condemn a nobleman!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Pray God he may acquit him of suspicion!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I thank thee, Meg; these words content me much.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Re-enter SUFFOLK

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How now! why look'st thou pale? why tremblest thou?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where is our uncle? what's the matter, Suffolk?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Dead in his bed, my lord; Gloucester is dead.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Marry, God forfend!

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: God's secret judgment: I did dream to-night

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: The duke was dumb and could not speak a word.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: KING HENRY VI swoons

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How fares my lord? Help, lords! the king is dead.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Rear up his body; wring him by the nose.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Run, go, help, help! O Henry, ope thine eyes!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: He doth revive again: madam, be patient.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O heavenly God!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How fares my gracious lord?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Comfort, my sovereign! gracious Henry, comfort!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What, doth my Lord of Suffolk comfort me?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Came he right now to sing a raven's note,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose dismal tune bereft my vital powers;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And thinks he that the chirping of a wren,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: By crying comfort from a hollow breast,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can chase away the first-conceived sound?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hide not thy poison with such sugar'd words;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Lay not thy hands on me; forbear, I say;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Their touch affrights me as a serpent's sting.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou baleful messenger, out of my sight!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Upon thy eye-balls murderous tyranny

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sits in grim majesty, to fright the world.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Look not upon me, for thine eyes are wounding:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Yet do not go away: come, basilisk,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And kill the innocent gazer with thy sight;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For in the shade of death I shall find joy;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: In life but double death, now Gloucester's dead.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why do you rate my Lord of Suffolk thus?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Although the duke was enemy to him,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet he most Christian-like laments his death:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And for myself, foe as he was to me,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Might liquid tears or heart-offending groans

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or blood-consuming sighs recall his life,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I would be blind with weeping, sick with groans,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Look pale as primrose with blood-drinking sighs,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
